title: Jonah's Flight
shortSummary: Jonah 1 recounts the prophet Jonah’s initial call from God to preach repentance to Nineveh and his subsequent attempt to flee from God's presence by sailing to Tarshish. The chapter highlights God's sovereign control over nature and human affairs, culminating in Jonah being swallowed by a great fish, setting the stage for his eventual obedience.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - The prophetic ministry of Jonah during the reign of Jeroboam II in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Jonah
keyCharacters.description: A Hebrew prophet called by God to preach repentance to Nineveh, who initially disobeys and attempts to flee from God's command.

keyCharacters.name: Shipmaster
keyCharacters.description: The captain of the ship at Joppa who confronts Jonah about his behavior during the storm and urges him to pray to his God.

keyCharacters.name: Mariners
keyCharacters.description: The sailors on the ship who fear the storm, cast lots to identify the cause of the calamity, and ultimately throw Jonah overboard to calm the sea.

definitions.definition: A distant port city, often associated with the western Mediterranean, representing a place far away from Nineveh and from God's command.
A method of casting or drawing lots used in biblical times to discern God's will or identify a cause of a situation.
A violent storm at sea, symbolizing God's judgment and power over creation.
An offering made to God as an act of worship, repentance, or thanksgiving, often involving the slaughter of an animal.

outline.heading: God’s Command to Jonah
outline.description: God calls Jonah to go to Nineveh and proclaim judgment because of its great wickedness, establishing the divine mission and purpose of the prophet.

outline.heading: Jonah’s Attempt to Flee
outline.description: Jonah disobeys God’s command by boarding a ship to Tarshish, illustrating human resistance to divine will and the futility of fleeing from God.

outline.heading: The Storm at Sea
outline.description: God sends a violent storm threatening the ship, demonstrating His sovereign control over nature and judgment against disobedience.

outline.heading: The Mariners’ Response and Jonah’s Identification
outline.description: The shipmaster urges Jonah to pray; the sailors cast lots to find the cause of the storm, and Jonah admits his identity and disobedience, highlighting accountability before God.

outline.heading: Jonah Cast Overboard and the Sea Calms
outline.description: Jonah instructs the sailors to throw him into the sea to calm the storm; upon doing so, the sea becomes calm, leading the sailors to fear and worship the LORD.

outline.heading: Jonah Swallowed by the Great Fish
outline.description: God appoints a great fish to swallow Jonah, preserving his life and setting the stage for his repentance and renewed obedience.

application: Trust in God's sovereign plan even when His commands challenge your desires or understanding.
Recognize that fleeing from God’s calling leads to turmoil; obedience brings peace and blessing.
In times of crisis, call upon God in prayer and encourage others to seek Him as well.
Repentance and surrender to God’s will can restore broken fellowship and open the way for divine mercy.

keyVerses.text: Arise, go to Nineveh, that great city, and cry against it; for their wickedness is come up before me.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s call to Jonah and His concern for the wickedness of Nineveh, emphasizing divine justice and mercy.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto them, Take me up, and cast me forth into the sea; so shall the sea be calm unto you: for I know that for my sake this great tempest is upon you.
keyVerses.significance: Jonah’s confession acknowledges his responsibility for the storm and shows his willingness to accept consequences, illustrating accountability.

keyVerses.text: So they took up Jonah, and cast him forth into the sea: and the sea ceased from her raging.
keyVerses.significance: This verse demonstrates God's control over nature and the power of obedience to bring peace and deliverance.

keyVerses.text: Now the LORD had prepared a great fish to swallow up Jonah. And Jonah was in the belly of the fish three days and three nights.
keyVerses.significance: God’s provision of the great fish preserves Jonah’s life and foreshadows resurrection themes, underscoring God’s mercy and purpose.
